thread.title: Utah State football: 5 questions with a Fresno State expert
thread.title_full: Utah State football: 5 questions with a Fresno State expert | Deseret News

author: Ryan McDonald
title: Utah State football: 5 questions with a Fresno State expert
text:
The Deseret News caught up with Marek Warszawski, a columnist at the Fresno Bee, to examine the Bulldogs' 1-4 start.
Upcoming Games USU   5 questions with an East Carolina insider Utah enemy camp: Five questions with a Cal beat writer 
The matchup: Utah State at Fresno State, Saturday
8:30 p.m. MDT, TV: CBS Sports Network
Bulldog Stadium, Fresno, California

Riding a big win over Colorado State last weekend, up next for the Utah State Aggies is a date Saturday with the Fresno State Bulldogs, a team that has struggled to a 1-4 start.
The Deseret News caught up with Fresno Bee columnist Marek Warszawski to discuss off-the-field issues and trouble in the trenches that have plagued the Bulldogs, as well as what Tim DeRuyter's team is anticipating this weekend against Utah State.
Whatâ€™s the quarterback situation heading into Saturday after Zack Greenlee was charged on Tuesday with possession of alcohol by a minor? 
MW: Greenlee served a one-game suspension against San Jose State in the week following his arrest. I do not expect there to be further punishment just because he's been charged. Fresno State already lost two of its four scholarship quarterbacks to season-ending injuries. I would expect Greenlee and Kilton Anderson to both play Saturday.
What's the morale of the team after combining the Zack Greenlee situation, the dismissal of linebacker Michael Lazarus on Tuesday and the losing streak the Bulldogs are experiencing? 
MW: I'm not in the locker room, but you've got to think morale is less than stellar considering the 1-4 start and quarterback mess. (I) Have not seen any outward signs of dissension or lack of effort. Still a little early for that.
What do they need to do to start righting the ship on the field? 
MW: That's a tricky one because this team has so many weaknesses. More than anything they've been beaten in the trenches -- on both sides of the ball. There's no easy fix when you're getting physically manhandled up front.
Are there any team strengths the squad will focus on to try to bring some success? 
MW: Tailback Marteze Waller is expected to play Saturday after leaving last week's loss to San Diego State with concussion symptoms. Even if he doesn't, Fresno State will try to establish some sort of running game. There's talent at receiver, if someone can get them the ball with more consistency.
Is there anything in particular with the matchup against Utah State that players and coaches are talking about as points of emphasis? 
MW: Fresno State is expecting a physical game, especially from the Aggies' front seven, which doesn't bode well. The Bulldogs get good crowd support (by MW standards), but if Utah State builds an early lead while the offense continues to sputter, the environment won't be much of a factor.
Ryan McDonald is a sports reporter at DeseretNews.com . Follow him on Twitter @ryanwmcdonald.
